ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course has taught me an incredible amount about social emotions. To name but a few, I have learned how emotions are conceptually defined; what distinguished a "basic" emotion (to the extent any such exists) from other emotions; how emotions can be socially functional or dysfunctional; how the academic literature is generally split in two camps, a constructivist and positivist one; and so on so forth.
I learned a lot about emotions and the different factors that can have a big influence in how one expresses and experiences emotions.

I've learned a great deal about the interpersonal aspect of emotions and the consequences it has on our lives. I've learned to write proper social psychology papers, and was able to take part in very thought-provoking and fun conversations with my classmates in this seminar.
I gained basic overview of emotions like their functions, use, and individual differences
I loved deep-diving into specific emotions with Dr. Clark and the class. It really strengthened my critical thinking of emotions and their influences.

Engaged with material on emotions in social contexts with the presupposition that emotions serve some sort of social function! Read and critiqued psychological articles and discussed findings and design in class.
I think this class taught me a lot about emotions and helped a lot in developing my writing skills
I learned more about emotions, their social functions, and how they play out in our everyday lives.
I feel like I got a much deeper understanding of how we define human emotions and the various nuances of how we express these emotions both inwardly and outwardly.
Learning more deeply about the functions of different emotions

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I very much enjoyed the course, including its structure and content. I only have two suggestions for improvement. One is to, if possible, include more graduate students, and to ensure that expectations for graduate students are clearly defined. The second is to make sure to provide feedbackespecially on research ideas and progressalong the way. Again, this is primarily true for graduate students and does not subtract from my overall assessment of the course as excellent.
I think the format of the class was great. The papers and reading responses were nice and not too burdensome.

Absolutely no weaknesses. This course is amazing and Professor Clark is the most caring, welcoming, and kind instructor I've ever met. She manage to create an extremely welcoming and safe environment, and the conversations we had and the insights I derived from them are extremely valuable.

Strengths: Very engaging classes/topic matter
Weaknesses: I wish there was more of a rubric for the essays

Serious strengths of this course are Dr. Clark, and the selection of students from social science majors and the masters programs. Dr. Clark has unparalleled knowledge of existing research regarding social emotions. Some of the best classes, though, were when the entire seminar spoke equally and students unpacked theories and offered new ideas. 
My only thoughts for improving the course might be to have some more interactive activities. It was often (too) easy to sit back and listen without offering comments.

prof. clark is great and our discussions were always really interesting. The workload is a bit high, normal senior seminars will only have one reading response due each week, but this class had two which i felt was a bit much, but overall they were not too bad.

Strengths - very engaging instructor, very interesting seminar topics
Weaknesses - perhaps could be more seminar-style, sometimes class felt like a lecture
I really enjoyed the combination of discussion and lecture of this course. It was interactive without putting too much pressure on each student to be constantly contributing.

Great discussion seminar where I felt very comfortable participating and where Professor Clark was very involved and enabled student discussion. Some improvement could me to change up the structure curriculum so its not the same every time, even though the topics were different the discussions and way of discussing the topics were very similar

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I absolutely would recommend this course to students interested in emotions or, more broadly, interpersonal relationships.
yes if you're interested in emotions.
yes! the professor is wonderful and the discussions were really engaging. the content is easy to relate to real life so its always interesting.

ABSOLUTELY! You'll be so so grateful for having taken this course and having met Professor Clark; she is an absolute angel -- the most caring and welcoming instructor I've ever met! She's also huge in the field of social psychology, and is an amazing mentor.
Yes, if you are a senior in the social sciences, it is a great course to take in your final year. In addition to the material, you meet some great students in your major or in the grad school.
Yes. This course teaches incredible life skills and social emotional awareness that can be translated into anything in life.

Yes!!! Would wholeheartedly recommend this course. Not only is Professor Clark amazing, the subject matter is incredibly interesting and the course is set up such that each student can have a high level of engagement without an overwhelming workload. By far my favorite class I took this semester, and one of my top three Ive taken as a cognitive science major!
yes, for psych majors its a great dicussions based class
YES. i found this class very interesting and really changed how i think about emotions
I would recommend this course to another student if they are interested in learning more about emotions and why we experience them when we do!

I would absolutely recommend this course. Professor Clark is so kind, passionate, and always willing to help students. I am not a morning person but was always happy to get up to go to this class at 9am!
Yes! If you need a interesting but chill psychology course
